update.description:
Continuation of pull request #1600.

3D Visuals move in response to the values input in the dialog. 

Didn't add a unit test for the visuals because all (most?) functions are covered by the dialog's unit test.

What's still missing:

* Mouse interactions

* Floating text
update.title: Add visuals to the Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw: We use it to store custom data to an object. When the mouse is clicked, ogre gives us back the object that's clicked but we also need to know which gazebo Visual it's attached to. So to do that, we store the Visual name in the object
content.html: We use it to store custom data to an object. When the mouse is clicked, ogre gives us back the object that's clicked but we also need to know which gazebo Visual it's attached to. So to do that, we store the Visual name in the object

content.raw: I'm not very sure about how they work either, they're somehow related to how objects are found in the scene. Without this, clicking on the force/torque visuals won't select the link, for example. And in the future, interactions with them wouldn't be possible.
content.html: I'm not very sure about how they work either, they're somehow related to how objects are found in the scene. Without this, clicking on the force/torque visuals won't select the link, for example. And in the future, interactions with them wouldn't be possible.

content.raw:
* Multiple dialogs: yes, you should be able to open as many dialogs as wanted for the same model/link.

* RTS visuals: I thought of just allowing them for now since we don't have the pink circles yet. They should not disappear strangely though.
content.html:
• Multiple dialogs: yes, you should be able to open as many dialogs as wanted for the same model/link.

  • RTS visuals: I thought of just allowing them for now since we don't have the pink circles yet. They should not disappear strangely though.

pull_request.title: Add visuals to the Apply Force/Torque dialog

pullrequest.title: Add visuals to the Apply Force/Torque dialog

content.raw:
Probably should have mentioned this in the last PR but I didn't try testing it: I can open multiple dialogs for the same model, is this expected?

In this branch, the rotate/translate/scale visuals for a model become visible in the normal way even when the Force/Torque dialog is open for that model. I remember it wasn't like this in the original PR. Is this going to be added later or are the RTS axes now allowed?

Been playing around with it for a while with many-linked models and seen no crashes so far, but I think I did see some strangeness with the Rotate axes disappearing permanently while the dialog was up. I'll try to see if I can reproduce that reliably.
content.html:
Probably should have mentioned this in the last PR but I didn't try testing it: I can open multiple dialogs for the same model, is this expected?

In this branch, the rotate/translate/scale visuals for a model become visible in the normal way even when the Force/Torque dialog is open for that model. I remember it wasn't like this in the original PR. Is this going to be added later or are the RTS axes now allowed?

Been playing around with it for a while with many-linked models and seen no crashes so far, but I think I did see some strangeness with the Rotate axes disappearing permanently while the dialog was up. I'll try to see if I can reproduce that reliably.

content.raw:
I actually started doing this, but I gave up because it's a very simplistic implementation and I ended up tailoring specifically for this case. It doesn't keep the up direction for example, which I think is needed for a more generally useful function.

Something like this is also done at [JointVisual](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/bf0316ec8b6bdfd79fdee0c1ff61f56fdcf00c60/gazebo/rendering/JointVisual.cc#cl-153).
content.html:
I actually started doing this, but I gave up because it's a very simplistic implementation and I ended up tailoring specifically for this case. It doesn't keep the up direction for example, which I think is needed for a more generally useful function.

Something like this is also done at JointVisual.

content.raw:
man, at some point we really need a PR making this a member function of `Quaternion` (it's needed in handsim too)

edit: oh, actually, the need I was thinking of was overridden--thinking of something unrelated--but expanding the math library with more fun linear algebra tools is a good future goal
content.html:
man, at some point we really need a PR making this a member function of Quaternion (it's needed in handsim too)

edit: oh, actually, the need I was thinking of was overridden--thinking of something unrelated--but expanding the math library with more fun linear algebra tools is a good future goal

content.html:
You could shorten 62-89 a bit by doing something like:

std::vector<std::string> entityNames = {"__FORCE_SHAFT__", "__FORCE_HEAD__", "__TORQUE_TUBE__", "__TORQUE_HEAD__"};

for (std::string entityName : entityNames)
{
  std::string name = this->GetName() entityName;
  if (manager->hasEntity(name));
    manager->destroyMovableObject(manager->getEntity(name));
}

and another loop for the sceneNode objects.
